[1/13/24, 10:05:18â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: Honestly a big part of it for me is I like record shopping. Going into the store and browsing talking to the staff talking about music and then investing in something. I think physically owning the record means you then have a kind of commitment to it that makes you more likely to pay attention when listening and look for enjoyment in it. This makes me more engaged as a music fan and less passive the way Spotify (and the skip button) let you be. I also like the big pretty artwork. And reading the sleeve note because I'm a massive geek .
[1/13/24, 10:06:15â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: Another good reason. Many awesome records like that aren't available on Spotify
[1/13/24, 10:07:18â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: Great way to support artists as well.

[1/15/24, 9:55:07â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: I think this is understandable at least the first two because of reasons.

1) in general most acts' first/early albums is/are better than their newest/latter albums (obviously there are many exceptions to this but I think it is more often true that way round than the reverse)

2) Often the album that wins you over to a band will be your favourite of theirs (again not always but probably true 50+% of the time)

[1/16/24, 12:30:58â€¯PM] Rory Edwards: I will quite often do the best three or four tunes from an album without a modicum of guilt.

[5/10/24, 11:36:59â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: I like this album a lot, which makes sense given it's the most Rory Edwards album ever. Probably my second favorite Frank album nowadays. Showcases various aspects of his style really well, nice and varied turning up the noise in places and the heartstrings in others, no song based on a terrible metaphor, huge insight into his story and character which I find really relatable despite my lack of drug addiction.
[5/10/24, 11:42:56â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: Is running not a drug then?
[5/10/24, 11:43:02â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: ğŸ˜œ
[5/10/24, 11:43:06â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: Maybe the thing I like about it best though is how strong it is thematically. It closes off a chapter in his life with several of the songs (most notably the Resurrectionists) referring directly back to earlier work. Frank's music has basically been all about the mess he was in and his recovery and although he still has his wobbles he seems basically there. Leaving London, settling down with his partner, and reconciling with his dad are all things that happened but they are also symbolic of that growth.

[6/14/24, 9:39:35â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: Interested to hear thoughts on Kraftwerk. I can't say I love them to be honest but you can hear how influential they are on this record. That steady ratcheting build up underpins near enough every dance track forever. My only complaint about some of the tunes on this is that they don't really resolve, it's like they fall in love with a single sound and just keep playing it for six minutes. When they do land though it's amazing, beautiful cinematic soundscapes despite having almost no vocal to speak of (sic). Metropolis I think the best example on this one.

[7/12/24, 8:38:43â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: An early version of the group called Girl's Tyme appeared on "Star Search" â€<This message was edited>
[7/12/24, 8:38:44â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: 1990â€“1997: Early beginnings and Girl's Tyme
In 1990, BeyoncÃ© Knowles met LaTavia Roberson at an audition for a girl group.[8] Based in Houston, Texas, they were joined to a group that performed rapping and dancing. Kelly Rowland, who relocated to Knowles' house because of family issues, joined them in 1992. Originally named Girl's Tyme, they were eventually cut down to six members including TÃ¡mar Davis and sisters Nikki and Nina Taylor.[9][10] With Knowles and Rowland, Girl's Tyme attracted nationwide attention:[9] west-coast R&B producer Arne Frager flew to Houston to see them. He brought them to his studio, The Plant Recording Studios, in Northern California, with focus on Knowles' vocals because Frager thought she had personality and the ability to sing.[9] With efforts to sign Girl's Tyme to a major record deal, Frager's strategy was to debut the group in Star Search, the biggest talent show on national TV at the time.[9] However, they lost the competition because, according to Knowles, their choice of song was wrong;[11] they were actually rapping instead of singing.[8]

[8/13/24, 9:23:07â€¯PM] David Thomas: relistening to this sitting in my car in a massive thunderstorm - we have a last minute house showing (house is up for sale), so we had to clear out of the house with 15 minutes notice, after we'd been out for happy hour; so i've had 2 beers, and my dogs sitting next to me shivering cos she's afraid of thunder so i can't walk her.  i think this EP is magical - both albert and B.B. are powerful in their own ways (especially that 1st track on the B.B album), but i think both suffer from being succesful in a genre that inherently requires someone to be at their lowest; i don't want to hear a blues song about going out to find women (it always sounds a little creepy/unsettling with hindsight) - i want to hear blues song about loosing your house, or loosing your dog, or your heart - heart ache and longing, not upbeat the joy that BB king aims to leaves you with. The Scottish Album of the year award's longlist https://www.sayaward.com/ came out yesterday and the big rock team were super chuffed that three big rock alumni made the list! You may have seen our post on social media. The panel whittles down the longlist from a huge list of nominations (https://www.sayaward.com/eligible) and has been running for 13 years now (https://www.sayaward.com/history). 

Pick any album associated with the award.

[12/2/24, 4:24:00â€¯AM] Fergus Neville: Quite early for a full review, but so far they're great. I've never had noise-cancelling headphones before and they're amazing! I'm currently listening to Low on the train and I can actually hear the music which is a big difference from previous headphones where I'd only attempt to play loud bassy music in a situation with lots of background noise. I just took them off to have my ticket checked and was almost deafened by how loud the train and other passengers were!

There's a wee app to play around with the equaliser etc but I've not used that too much yet. Pretty comfy so far although I've not worn them for a long period of time. IT services have stuck a crappy wee St Andrews asset tag sticker on them which is a bit annoying, but a small price to pay for zero price headphones.

[12/24/24, 12:50:11â€¯PM] Neil Tilston: Apparently the title "Time out of mind" is a reference to what Dylan saw as a group of songs that had been rattling around his head for years but he'd never managed to flesh out. [2/7/25, 11:15:08â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: He was struggling with age and injuries by the 1956 Olympics along with several of his contemporaries. [3/5/25, 3:34:54â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: Last night's opening set - "Funky Gunners play New Orleans for Mardi Gras (presented by Neil)" is now available to listen back-

https://www.mixcloud.com/jamradio/funky-gunners-040325-part-1-funky-gunners-play-new-orleans-for-mardi-gras-presented-by-neil/

Link also available in linktree in Bio/story/highlights on insta profile .

This Tuesday is Mardi Gras! This day is celebrated all over the world but no one does it like New Orleans. In carnival season the streets of New Orleans are filled with parades, music and dancing.

Neil's love of New Orleans music started when he watched the incredible HBO TV series Treme following the lives of people in post Hurricane Katrina New Orleans and featuring many real music legends including Dr John and members of The Rebirth Bras Band. Ten years ago a trip to New Orleans fuelled Neil's love for the people, place and  music from this incredible and enduring city.

Expect to hear jazz, funk, soul, brass bands and more!

The Hot 8 Brass Band - Papa Was A Rolling Stone

[4/25/25, 3:24:39â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: I picked this album and theme after watching the excellent doc "The Man from Mo Wax" all about James Lavelle and his incredible record label. This album is at the epicenter of the story. In truth it's really DJ shadow's solo album but I'd highly recommend watching the film and seeing how James and Shadow go from enthusiastic collaborators to Shadow loathing James for taking credit for what was basically his album. An incredible record and unsurprisingly UNKLE never replicated it (although they do have some killer tunes) because their primary artist left after one album!
[4/25/25, 3:26:21â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: I found this an interesting album her voice is quite striking and on some tunes I thought it was truly awesome and on others I found it a little annoying. [4/25/25, 3:30:59â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: A fantastic record. It's easy to write UB40 off as music for middle aged middle class dinner parties because of how big some of those popier covers they did later were so massive. But early UB40 and this album in particular show that at their best UB40 were right up there with the likes of The Specials for making music that was at once English and also Carribbean fully showcasing the incredible artistic influence of the windrush generation in British music. I'd argue this record contains some of the greatest dub tracks ever recorded outside of Jamaica

Artist: Ed Sheeran
Release Date: Imaginary â€“ let's say August 2025
ğŸŒŒ Concept & Vibe

"Loop Theory" is Ed Sheeranâ€™s bold venture into the world of house music, blending his signature acoustic storytelling with hypnotic beats, soulful drops, and deep grooves. The album explores themes of connection, rhythm, and emotional resonance through the lens of electronic soundscapes.
[8/22/25, 7:32:04â€¯AM] Fergus Neville: ğŸ§© Tracklist

    Pulse & Poetry
    A warm, melodic opener with Sheeranâ€™s vocals layered over a chilled house groove. Lyrics explore the rhythm of relationships.

    Neon Heartbeat
    A club-ready anthem with a driving bassline and shimmering synths. Think Ibiza sunset meets London soul.

    Echoes of You
    Deep house with a melancholic twist. Vocal chops and ambient textures create a haunting yet danceable track.

    Vinyl Dreams
    Retro-inspired house with vinyl crackles and jazzy chords. A nod to Sheeranâ€™s love for classic sounds.

    Loop Theory
    The title track. A hypnotic, looping beat with layered harmonies and a spoken-word bridge about time and memory.

    Midnight Messages
    A late-night banger with emotional lyrics about unsent texts and missed connections.

    Frequency of Us
    Uplifting vocal house with gospel-inspired backing vocals and a euphoric drop.

    Digital Flame
    A darker, tech-house influenced track exploring love in the digital age.

    Rewind & Replay
    A nostalgic tune with a funky groove and lyrics about second chances.

    Final Fade
    A slow-burning closer with ambient pads and a stripped-back vocal performance, ending the album on a reflective note.

[9/13/25, 2:52:44â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: Oops
[9/13/25, 2:53:18â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: I think there are some bands where greatest hits records are totally justified
[9/13/25, 3:43:58â€¯AM] Neil Tilston: My view is that talking heads are a bit like Radiohead. But not like Radiohead.

Talking heads came out of the CBGB scene so we're a bit punk but definitely more post punk. And Fergus pick shows that sound. However after that they started being more influenced by a producer (Brian Eno) and listening to predominantly psychedelic funk like parliament and afrobeat like Fella Kuti which had a massive influence on their sound so they ended up making very different rock albums from anyone else.

Radiohead came out of the 90s Alt rock scene so were a bit grungy but also wrongly pigeon-holed as britpop. Pablo honey and arguably the bends showcase that sound. However after that they started being more influenced by a producer (Nigel Godrich) and listening to predominantly idm like Aphex Tein and post rock like Sigur Ros which had a massive influence on their sound so they ended up making very different rock albums from anyone else.

So a very similar journey albeit with different starting points and influences.

That said two of the most interesting rock bands sound wise. â€<This message was edited>
[9/13/25, 4:13:19â€¯AM] Rory Edwards: I can wear that. I don't like them as much as Radiohead. Taylor doesn't really have a consistent 'sound', she has themes, and co-opts sounds alongside talented producers. She is wise though imo to usually stick to one a record. The thing about those Talking Heads albums is that I was usually jumping between who it sounded a bit like. Some would say that's a good thing and varied. â€<This message was edited>

[11/10/25, 2:26:41â€¯PM] Neil Tilston: Lux was described by a press release as exploring lyrical themes of "feminine mystique, transformation, and transcendence", and its songs are inspired both by RosalÃ­a's romantic relationships and her relationship with God. Its track listing is split across four movements, with lyrics in fourteen languagesâ€”RosalÃ­a's native Catalan and Spanish, along with Arabic, English, French, German, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Latin, Mandarin, Portuguese, Sicilian, and Ukrainian. Each language's lyrics correspond to the life of a different female saint. A significant portion of the album's creation, which took between two and three years overall, was dedicated to learning how to sing in the various languages. RosalÃ­a often started songs by sketching out rough lyrics with Google Translate before taking her drafts to professional translators and phoneticians. Music critics and journalists generally classified Lux as either classical music or experimental pop music with classical influences.
[11/10/25, 2:29:35â€¯PM] Neil Tilston: Imagine the conversation with the label

"Sorry folks this is going to take a couple of years longer than expected. Just need to learn how to sing in fourteen languages"
